synonyms: lung apices included on both sides
costophrenic angles included on both sides
CP angles obscured by soft tissue

notes: Poor inspiration or malrotation does not reduce score unless it causes exclusion or obscuration of the apices or CP angles.
Lordotic AP, elevated shoulders, or arms-down positioning can obscure apices despite inclusion; treat as no if clinically non-diagnostic.

any_of.term: apex excluded/cut off (specify side if stated)
costophrenic angle excluded/cut off (specify side if stated)

synonyms: CP angles obscured by soft tissue
apices fully visible on both sides

disambiguation_rules: ‘Blunted CP angles’ from effusion count as included if the angles are within the field of view and not obscured. Do not mark no solely for blunting.
‘Apical pleural cap,’ apical fibrosis, or calcification are pathology terms; if apices are within the field and not obscured, count as included.
‘Hemidiaphragms included’ is supportive but not sufficient; explicit mention of the lateral costophrenic angles/recesses is preferred.
Prefer laterality when available: “right apex clipped,” “left CP angle excluded.”
Portable AP with lordotic angulation that projects clavicles over the apices is no if it prevents confident assessment of the apices.

synonyms: medial ends of clavicles unequal distance from spinous processes
asymmetric rib cage appearance due to rotation

disambiguation_rules: Rotation is assessed by comparing the distance from the medial ends of the clavicles to the spinous processes of the thoracic vertebrae.
mild rotation (<5 mm difference) is common and may not be clinically significant unless it impacts interpretation; count as yes only if explicitly noted or clearly described.
Do not confuse scoliosis or rib deformity with rotation; those should not trigger yes unless rotation is explicitly stated.
Rotation direction can be described relative to the patient: ‘rotated to right’ means the right clavicle appears further from midline.
Portable AP views may show more frequent rotation due to patient condition; still mark yes if rotation is present.

Does the chest X-ray show cardiomegaly?.projection_hint: Assume frontal chest radiograph (PA preferred; AP portable may exaggerate heart size)

synonyms: transverse cardiac diameter more than half thoracic diameter

notes: AP projection magnifies cardiac size and can overestimate CTR
Poor inspiration, malrotation, or lordotic positioning can falsely increase apparent heart size
Pericardial effusion may enlarge the silhouette without true myocardial enlargement

disambiguation_rules: For adults on PA view use CTR > 0.50 as cardiomegaly
For AP portable views avoid relying solely on CTR unless clearly stated as enlarged and consider clinical context
In infants and young children a higher CTR threshold may be physiologic and should not be auto-flagged as cardiomegaly unless explicitly stated
Pericardial effusion can cause an enlarged cardiac silhouette and is often described as globular or water-bottle shaped which may be reported as enlarged silhouette rather than cardiomegaly
Chest wall deformities including pectus excavatum, severe scoliosis, or rotation can alter apparent heart size
Adequate inspiration is preferred with at least 6 anterior or 10 posterior ribs visible on PA to avoid pseudo-enlargement

Is there evidence of pulmonary congestio.projection_hint: Assume frontal chest radiograph (PA/AP); consider that supine/AP positioning may mask upper lobe diversion

synonyms: prominent apical vessels relative to bases
no evidence of pulmonary venous hypertension

disambiguation_rules: Pulmonary congestion refers to radiographic signs of elevated pulmonary venous pressure, often from left heart failure.
On upright PA radiographs, upper lobe venous diversion (cephalization) is a classic early sign; this may be absent in supine or semi-erect AP views.
Interstitial edema appears as Kerley A and B lines, peribronchial cuffing, and diffuse reticular opacities.
Alveolar edema with perihilar opacities (‘bat wing’ pattern) can also be described as pulmonary congestion in the appropriate context.
Do not confuse perihilar opacities from infection or lymphoma with congestion unless venous redistribution or interstitial edema is also noted.
In chronic lung disease, vascular prominence may not indicate acute congestion—rely on explicit statements or multiple supportive findings.

synonyms: loss of sharpness of right CP angle
concave upper border of right pleural fluid
right lateral decubitus shows fluid shift
no blunting of right costophrenic angle
no blunting of right costophrenic angle
concave upper border of right pleural fluid

disambiguation_rules: right pleural effusion is suggested by blunting or obliteration of the right costophrenic angle on upright PA film.
The meniscus sign refers to a concave upward contour of pleural fluid seen on upright imaging.
Layering of fluid on right lateral decubitus films confirms its free-flowing nature.
Small effusions may be seen only on decubitus or ultrasound; for radiograph-only evaluation, rely on explicit report statements.
Pleural thickening or scarring may mimic blunting; do not classify as effusion unless fluid is described.
Loculated effusions may not show a classic meniscus; look for atypical curvilinear or lenticular opacities.

synonyms: loss of sharpness of left CP angle
concave upper border of left pleural fluid
left lateral decubitus shows fluid shift
no blunting of left costophrenic angle
no blunting of left costophrenic angle
concave upper border of left pleural fluid

disambiguation_rules: left pleural effusion is suggested by blunting or obliteration of the left costophrenic angle on upright PA film.
The meniscus sign refers to a concave upward contour of pleural fluid seen on upright imaging.
Layering of fluid on left lateral decubitus films confirms its free-flowing nature.
Small effusions may be seen only on decubitus or ultrasound; for radiograph-only evaluation, rely on explicit report statements.
Pleural thickening or scarring may mimic blunting; do not classify as effusion unless fluid is described.
Loculated effusions may not show a classic meniscus; look for atypical curvilinear or lenticular opacities.
Pulmonary opacities include consolidation, ground-glass opacity, interstitial markings, or nodular opacities within the right lung field.
Do not confuse pleural effusion with parenchymal opacity; blunting of the costophrenic angle alone does not count.
right lung is divided into upper, middle, and lower zones; location-specific descriptors should still count as yes.
Air bronchograms suggest alveolar consolidation and should be considered an opacity.
Post-surgical changes, scarring, or atelectasis can appear as opacities; if described as opacity, still count as yes unless clearly stated as old or unchanged.
Pulmonary opacities include consolidation, ground-glass opacity, interstitial markings, or nodular opacities within the left lung field.
Do not confuse pleural effusion with parenchymal opacity; blunting of the costophrenic angle alone does not count.
left lung is divided into upper and lower zones (lingula included in upper zone for descriptive purposes); location-specific descriptors should still count as yes.
Air bronchograms suggest alveolar consolidation and should be considered an opacity.
Post-surgical changes, scarring, or atelectasis can appear as opacities; if described as opacity, still count as yes unless clearly stated as old or unchanged.

synonyms: loss of volume in right lung

disambiguation_rules: right-sided atelectasis is indicated by a combination of signs such as volume loss, fissure displacement, elevation of the hemidiaphragm, mediastinal shift toward the affected side, and vascular crowding.
Require at least two supportive signs to confidently classify as yes unless explicitly stated by the radiologist.
Mediastinal shift away from the right side suggests an alternative process such as tension pneumothorax, not atelectasis.
Post-surgical changes, scarring, or prior lobectomy can mimic volume loss; use clinical or historical context when available.
Segmental, lobar, or total lung collapse on the right should all be counted as yes if described as atelectasis or with equivalent signs.

synonyms: loss of volume in left lung

disambiguation_rules: left-sided atelectasis is indicated by a combination of signs such as volume loss, fissure displacement, elevation of the hemidiaphragm, mediastinal shift toward the affected side, and vascular crowding.
Require at least two supportive signs to confidently classify as yes unless explicitly stated by the radiologist.
Mediastinal shift away from the left side suggests an alternative process such as tension pneumothorax, not atelectasis.
Post-surgical changes, scarring, or prior lobectomy can mimic volume loss; use clinical or historical context when available.
Segmental, lobar, or total lung collapse on the left should all be counted as yes if described as atelectasis or with equivalent signs.

synonyms: no vascular markings beyond line right
no free air in right pleural space
no vascular markings beyond line right

disambiguation_rules: A pneumothorax is identified by the presence of a visceral pleural line with no lung markings peripheral to it.
In upright films, the air rises to the apex; in supine patients, look for the deep sulcus sign.
Avoid mistaking skin folds, bullae, or interlobar fissures for a pleural line; these may mimic pneumothorax.
Hyperlucency from overexposure or emphysema should not be classified as pneumothorax unless a pleural line is seen.
Tension pneumothorax is a separate diagnosis, but its underlying pneumothorax should still be marked as yes.

synonyms: no vascular markings beyond line left
no free air in left pleural space
no vascular markings beyond line left

disambiguation_rules: A pneumothorax is identified by the presence of a visceral pleural line with no lung markings peripheral to it.
In upright films, the air rises to the apex; in supine patients, look for the deep sulcus sign.
Avoid mistaking skin folds, bullae, or interlobar fissures for a pleural line; these may mimic pneumothorax.
Hyperlucency from overexposure or emphysema should not be classified as pneumothorax unless a pleural line is seen.
Tension pneumothorax is a separate diagnosis, but its underlying pneumothorax should still be marked as yes.
A pulmonary nodule is typically defined as a rounded or irregular opacity ≤3 cm in diameter, whereas a mass is >3 cm.
Count as yes if either a nodule or a mass is explicitly described, regardless of whether benign or malignant features are discussed.
Do not count calcified granulomas, old scars, or artifacts unless described as a current nodule or mass.
Multiple nodules or masses should still be counted as yes.
Terms like 'opacity' or 'lesion' should be linked to a focal finding; diffuse opacities are not nodules or masses.
An endotracheal tube is typically identified as a radiopaque line with a central lucency extending into the trachea.
Count as yes if an endotracheal tube is explicitly mentioned, regardless of position or tip location.
Do not count nasogastric or orogastric tubes as endotracheal tubes.
If the tube is malpositioned but still present, the answer remains yes.
If the report only mentions 'tube removed' or 'extubated', classify as no.
A gastric tube includes nasogastric (NG), orogastric (OG), and feeding tubes that traverse the esophagus into the stomach.
Count as yes if the tube is explicitly described, regardless of whether the tip position is in the correct location.
Do not confuse an endotracheal tube with a gastric tube.
If the tube is malpositioned but present, still count as yes.
If the report mentions 'tube removed' or 'no tube present', classify as no.
A central venous catheter (CVC) is identified as a radiopaque line coursing through a central vein, often terminating in the superior vena cava or right atrium.
Count as yes if any type of CVC is explicitly described, including tunneled, non-tunneled, or peripherally inserted central catheters (PICCs) if the report calls them central lines.
Differentiate CVC from other lines like Swan-Ganz catheters or dialysis catheters unless explicitly called a central line.
If the line is malpositioned but present, still count as yes.
If the report states the line has been removed, classify as no.
A central venous catheter (CVC) is identified as a radiopaque line coursing through a central vein, often terminating in the superior vena cava or right atrium.
Count as yes if any type of CVC is explicitly described, including tunneled, non-tunneled, or peripherally inserted central catheters (PICCs) if the report calls them central lines.
Differentiate CVC from other lines like Swan-Ganz catheters or dialysis catheters unless explicitly called a central line.
If the line is malpositioned but present, still count as yes.
If the report states the line has been removed, classify as no.
A cardiac pacemaker is typically identified by a radiopaque generator, often in the upper chest wall, with pacing leads extending into the heart.
Count as yes if any type of permanent pacemaker is explicitly described, including single-lead, dual-lead, or biventricular systems.
Differentiate pacemakers from implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) unless the report uses the generic term 'pacemaker'.
If the device is malfunctioning, displaced, or partially visualized, still count as yes.
If the report states the device has been removed, classify as no.
A chest tube (thoracostomy tube) is typically visualized as a radiopaque line with side holes, projecting into the pleural space.
Count as yes if any type of chest tube is explicitly described, regardless of indication (pneumothorax, effusion, empyema, postoperative drainage).
Do not confuse a central venous catheter or other lines for a chest tube.
If the tube is malpositioned but present, still count as yes.
If the report states the tube has been removed or is absent, classify as no.
Severity of pulmonary congestion is typically graded based on the progression from vascular redistribution (mild) to interstitial edema (moderate) to alveolar edema (severe).
Projection, patient position, and technical factors can affect apparent severity.
Small pleural effusions may accompany moderate or severe congestion but are not required for diagnosis.
Terms like 'equivocal' or 'questionable' should map to questionable unless there is stronger evidence for a higher grade.

any_of.term: meniscus reaches lateral chest wall mid-height

disambiguation_rules: Pleural effusion severity is graded based on the vertical height of the meniscus and degree of hemithorax opacification.
A 'questionable' grade applies when the finding is subtle or equivocal, often at the threshold of detection.
Small (mild) effusions typically blunt only the costophrenic angle without significant lateral wall contact.
moderate effusions reach mid-chest level and may obscure the diaphragm or contact the lateral wall.
severe effusions occupy most of the hemithorax, often with mediastinal shift if under tension.

any_of.term: meniscus reaches lateral chest wall mid-height
synonyms: fluid abutting lateral wall mid-level left

disambiguation_rules: Pleural effusion severity is graded based on the vertical height of the meniscus and degree of hemithorax opacification.
A 'questionable' grade applies when the finding is subtle or equivocal, often at the threshold of detection.
Small (mild) effusions typically blunt only the costophrenic angle without significant lateral wall contact.
moderate effusions reach mid-chest level and may obscure the diaphragm or contact the lateral wall.
severe effusions occupy most of the hemithorax, often with mediastinal shift if under tension.
Estimate percentage involvement of the right lung by summing visible airspace opacities across zones.
mild: less than 25% of lung involved; often localized or patchy.
moderate: 25–50% of lung involved, often multifocal.
severe: greater than 50% involvement, often confluent or diffuse.
questionable: extremely subtle findings with uncertain significance.
Estimate percentage involvement of the left lung by summing visible airspace opacities across zones.
mild: less than 25% of lung involved; often localized or patchy.
moderate: 25–50% of lung involved, often multifocal.
severe: greater than 50% involvement, often confluent or diffuse.
questionable: extremely subtle findings with uncertain significance.
